verse:
तव कथामृतं तप्तजीवनं कविभिरीडितं कल्मषापहम् ।
श्रवणमङ्गलं श्रीमदाततं भुवि गृणन्ति ये भूरिदा जनाः ॥
meaning: जो भगवान की ओर ले जाने के लिए पुस्तक लिखते हैं लेक्चर देते हैं समझाते हैं वो तो बहुत बड़े दानी हैं उनसे बड़ा कौन दानी होगा

terms.tapta-jīvanam: life for those aggrieved in the material world
terms.kalmaṣa-apaham: that which drives away sinful reactions

vedabase.translation: The nectar of Your words and the descriptions of Your activities are the life and soul of those suffering in this material world. These narrations, transmitted by learned sages, eradicate one’s sinful reactions and bestow good fortune upon whoever hears them. These narrations are broadcast all over the world and are filled with spiritual power. Certainly those who spread the message of Godhead are most munificent.
vedabase.purport: King Pratāparudra recited this verse to Śrī Caitanya Mahāprabhu during Lord Jagannātha’s Ratha-yātrā festival. While the Lord was resting in a garden, King Pratāparudra humbly entered and began massaging His legs and lotus feet. Then the King recited the Thirty-first Chapter of the Tenth Canto of the Śrīmad-Bhāgavatam, the songs of the gopīs. The Caitanya-caritāmṛta relates that when Lord Caitanya heard this verse, beginning tava kathāmṛtam, He immediately arose in ecstatic love and embraced King Pratāparudra. The incident is described in detail in the Caitanya-caritāmṛta (Madhya 14.4-18), and in his edition Śrīla Prabhupāda has given extensive commentary on it.

terms.तप्तजीवनं: which give life to the despondent

gpt.meaning: Your nectar like stories, which give life to the despondent, are praised by poets and destroy impurities. The world praises these auspicious and splendid stories, which bestow abundance on the people.

bard.meaning: your story full of struggle, desired by poets, destroyer of sins, auspicious to hear, constantly chanted on earth by generous people.Your story, full of struggle, desired by poets, destroyer of sins, auspicious to hear, constantly chanted on earth by generous people.
